text: it's tough terrain in Garamba National
Park where less than a hundred Rangers
are trying to protect the last of the
elephants across thousands of square
miles of grassland we joined one of the
foot patrols to a place where the
poachers last struck the grass is so
high the only way to see a carcass is
from the air and then to direct the
Rangers in well this elephant was
clearly killed by a poacher its ivory
tusks were hacked off it's been dead
about three weeks and there are another
four of these carcasses spread all
around here in the long grass they
arrived too late to catch the poachers
who were who were long gone thirty to
forty thousand elephants are being
killed in Africa every year and with
only around 400,000 left it's not going
to be long at this rate before they're
gone
and with so few boots on the ground
those responsible often get away with
the ivory good Alejandro wondered if she
would we followed their footprints one
of the Rangers told me but they lost the
trail
there are perhaps 1,300 elephants left
here they used to be 22,000 grambo was
one of Africa's first national parks and
a world heritage site originally set up
to protect the northern white rhino but
that has already been wiped out by
poachers now they're fighting to save
the elephants that are left in a place
surrounded by civil war and heavily
armed militia and that's why African
parks the group managing Garamba
is trying to train a small army but the
weapons are oh you hit even a close
target dug his ticket the new Peter this
Ranger explained how dangerous the work
is his patrol was ambushed by 40 men
probably from Sudan heavily armed and on
horseback eight Rangers had been killed
in the last year training Rangers takes
a lot of time and money and the men
they're up against a hardened fighters I
mean this really does feel like you're
fighting a war against poachers yeah
it's uh I think Garamba is probably
today the the forefront of conservation
in terms of dangers so I just don't
think there many other places which has
so much contact and so many threats to
one pockets we have here some poachers
are caught this local man was arrested
after a tip-off and ivory recovered they
make about twenty pounds a kilogram by
the time it reaches the market in Asia
it goes through at least 750 this is
worth a small fortune
then reports came in of another attack
and there were the carcasses just down
there by the river five of them one of
them a baby they're six we've just
spotted a little bit further up the
river from there it's hard to make out
from up here but you can see that their
faces have been cut off that the tusks
have been taken they need hundreds more
Rangers to protect Garamba on the
frontline of the poaching war the
elephants are fast disappearing Alice to
